(2) Augusta Murray (d. 1848)
(3) Augusta de Crespigny }} '''John Somerset Pakington, 1st Baron Hampton''' [[Order of the Bath|GCB]], [[Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council|PC]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (20 February 1799 – 9 April 1880), known as '''Sir John Pakington, Bt''' from 1846 to 1874, was a British [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] politician. ==Background and education== Born John Somerset Russell, Hampton was the son of William Russell and Elizabeth Pakington, the member of a prominent [[Worcestershire]] family. Elizabeth was the sister and heiress of Sir John Pakington, the 8th and last Baronet Pakington of Ailesbury. John Somerset was educated at [[Eton College|Eton]] and [[Oriel College, Oxford]] and assumed in 1830 by Royal License the surname of Pakington in lieu of his patronymic on inheriting the estates of his maternal uncle. These included [[Westwood House, Worcestershire|Westwood House in Worcestershire]] and Pakington moved in there with his first wife in 1832. ==Political career== Pakington was elected at the fourth attempt as the Tory [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Droitwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Droitwich]] in 1837, a seat he held until 1874. He was given office by Sir [[Robert Peel]] in 1841 and created in 1846 first Baronet Pakington of the second creation, of Westwood in the County of Worcester. He next served under [[Edward Smith-Stanley, 14th Earl of Derby|Lord Derby]] as [[Secretary of State for War and the Colonies]] in 1852 and was sworn of the [[Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council|Privy Council]] the same year. The government lasted only a year and in opposition he developed an interest in education reform, introducing in 1855 an unsuccessful Education Bill which foreshadowed the 1870 Act. With the Tories back in power he again held office under Lord Derby as [[List of the First Lords of the Admiralty|First Lord of the Admiralty]] from 1858 to 1859 and from 1866 to 1867. As First Lord he commissioned the first ironclad warship, HMS ''Warrior'', launched in 1860. Under Derby and his successor [[Benjamin Disraeli]] he was [[Secretary of State for War]] from 1867 to 1868. He was appointed a [[Order of the Bath|GCB]] in 1859. He lost his seat in the Commons in the 1874 election and was raised to the peerage as '''Baron Hampton''', of [[Hampton Lovett]] and of Westwood in the County of Worcester. [[File:John Somerset Pakington, Vanity Fair, 1870-02-12.jpg|left|thumb|Pakington caricatured by "ATn" in ''Vanity Fair'', 1870]] ==Other public appointments== He served for many years as chairman of the Worcestershire Quarter Sessions. He was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] in Jun, 1858.{{cite web|url=http://royalsociety.org/Lists-of-Royal-Society-Fellows-1660-2007/ |title=Lists of Royal Society Fellows 1660-2007 |publisher=The Royal Society |accessdate=4 August 2010 |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20100324095152/http://royalsociety.org:80/Lists-of-Royal-Society-Fellows-1660-2007/ |archivedate=24 March 2010 }} He was also President of the [[Royal Statistical Society]] from 1861 to 1863 and [[Her Majesty's Civil Service|Chief Civil Service]] [[Commissioner]] from 1875 until his death. ==Family== Lord Hampton married firstly Mary, daughter of Moreton Aglionby Slaney, on 14 August 1822. After her death in 1843 he married secondly Augusta, daughter of the Right Reverend [[George Murray (bishop)|George Murray]], on 2 June 1844. After her death in 1848 he married thirdly Augusta Anne, daughter of Thomas Champion de Crespigny and widow of [[Thomas Davies (MP)|Thomas Davies]], MP, on 5 June 1851. Lord Hampton died at his London home in April 1880, aged 81, and was succeeded by his son from his first marriage, John. ==References== {{reflist}} *{{DNB Cite|wstitle=Pakington, John Somerset}} *[http://www.1911encyclopedia.org/Pakington Classic Encyclopaedia] *[http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9504E1DB1F31EE3ABC4852DFB266838B699FDE&oref=slogin Obituary] [[The New York Times|New York Times]] 10 April 1880 *[http://books.google.com/books?id=3zEEAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA31&lpg=PA31&dq=%22george+murray%22+rochester&source=web&ots=TRbh3Rnh-2&sig=lSID0QEOLg3nZ14L1vKnJrqB-3k The peerage of the British empire as at present existing.] Page 31 Google Books ==External links== {{Commons category|John Pakington, 1st Baron Hampton}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{succession box | title = [[Droitwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Member of Parliament for Droitwich]] | years = 1837–1874 | before = [[John Barneby]] | after = [[John Corbett (industrialist)|John Corbett]]}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | before=[[Henry Grey, 3rd Earl Grey|The Earl Grey]] | title=[[Secretary of State for War and the Colonies]] | years=1852 | after=[[Henry Pelham-Clinton, 5th Duke of Newcastle|The Duke of Newcastle]]}} {{succession box | title = [[List of the First Lords of the Admiralty|First Lord of the Admiralty]] | years = 1858–1859 | before = [[Charles Wood, 1st Viscount Halifax|Sir Charles Wood, Bt]] | after = [[Edward Seymour, 12th Duke of Somerset|The Duke of Somerset]]}} {{succession box | title = [[List of the First Lords of the Admiralty|First Lord of the Admiralty]] | years = 1866–1867 | before = [[Edward Seymour, 12th Duke of Somerset|The Duke of Somerset]] | after = [[Henry Lowry-Corry (1803–1873)|Hon.
